Drug use and resulting homelessness have many root causes, so maybe we should withhold quick condemnation of every homeless person.  Yes, some of the alcohol/drug addicted homeless people made bad lifestyle choices and have ended up where they are as a result.  However, not all alcohol/drug addicted homeless people ended up this way because one day they decided this was the life they wanted to live. .

.

Hindering prosecution, interfering with a peace officer and concealing evidence are not of issue with police questioning.  If the officer wants information there is a process within the rule of law that allows the officer to get that information.  A subpoena is issued by the court and the questions are asked in court, under controlled circumstances.  Keep in mind part of the Miranda warning involves the right to have council present when answering questions (from and officer or a subpoena).  Remember, you don't get the rights in the Miranda warning when arrested, you always have them.  

The court is very clear in that a person never has to speak to a police officer.   In fact a number of decisions of the supreme court of the US not only clarify these rights, but state it is in the best interest of those being questioned to exercise their rights under the 5th amendment.

In short, a person should never answer questions from a law enforcement officer unless they genuinely want to.

There are two types of inclusionary zoning i.e. Market Rate Inclusionary Housing and Means Tested Inclusionary Housing.

Market Rate Inclusionary Housing is built to be affordable to a specific economic constituency. However, it may be rented by anyone with the ability to pay.

Means Tested Inclusionary Housing is built to be affordable to a specific economic constituency. However, only a range of buyers within a restricted MFI are eligible to participate. Only those at the top of that MFI range will find the property affordable. This class of housing is similar to Public Housing and in some cases may actually be Public Housing.

The question perpetually arises with inclusionary zoning, Public Housing and other attempts at Affordable Housing, which is never answered: For WHOM are these units being built and what statistical data has been used to determine the need by neighborhood?

Discussion of gravity waves has been ongoing for many decades.  Gravity waves are similar in concept to electromagnetic waves, i.e. radio, light, X-rays, etc.  Gravity, however, is much weaker than electromagnetic forces.  Just as electric current moving back and forth in an antenna creates radio waves, objects moving around each other in orbits emit gravitational waves.  Because gravity is so much weaker than electromagnetic forces, it takes truly massive objects to make gravitational waves we can detect.  Everybody expected gravitational waves to exist, the challenge was to make a receiver sensitive enough to detect them.  Basically no practical importance as far as human existence is concerned.  However, the detection of the gravitational waves is a brilliant feat of experimental physics.

In an age of internet porn, young people can easily seek to satisfy their curiosity and be exposed to very perverted conceptions of human sexuality. A more clinical curriculum with opportunities to ask real questions and have them answered without shame seems crucial for all young people, not just those lucky enough to grow up with informed and open parents willing to address the issues over the course of a child's development. I'd say the same for immunizations or other public health issues or if families decided that they only wanted their sons and not their daughters educated. But I think we absolutely agree that families need to accept a more active role, speaking early and often about sexuality, as young bodies gradually change.
